'''''Helvella lacunosa''''', known as the '''slate grey saddle''' or '''fluted black elfin saddle''' in North America, simply as the '''elfin saddle''' in Britain, is an [[Ascomycota|ascomycete]] [[fungus]] of the family [[Helvellaceae]]. It is probably the most common species in the genus ''[[Helvella]]''.<ref name=T.Laessoe>{{cite book | author = Thomas Laessoe | year = 1998 | title = Mushrooms (flexi bound) | publisher = Dorling Kindersley | isbn = 0-7513-1070-0}}</ref> The [[mushroom]] is readily identified by its irregularly shaped grey [[pileus (mycology)|cap]], fluted [[stipe (mycology)|stem]], and fuzzy undersurfaces. It is found in Eastern North America and in Europe, near [[deciduous]] and [[coniferous]] trees in summer and autumn.

==Taxonomy==
Scottish naturalist [[John Lightfoot (biologist)|John Lightfoot]] wrote of it in his 1777 work ''Flora Scotica'', calling ''Helvella mitra'', or curled helvella.<ref name=lightfoot>{{cite book | title=Flora Scotica: or, a systematic arrangement, in the Linnaean method, of the native plants of Scotland and the Hebrides | first=John | last=Lightfoot | volume= 2 | page=1047 | location=London |publisher= B. White | url=https://biodiversitylibrary.org/page/18951435}}</ref>

The fungus was formally described by Swedish botanist [[Adam Afzelius]] in 1783.<ref>{{cite journal | first=Adam |last=Afzelius | title=Helvella lacunosa | journal =Kungl. Svenska vetenskapsakademiens handlingar | series= 2 | volume=4| page= 304 | year=1783|language=Swedish | url=https://biodiversitylibrary.org/page/46983497}}</ref> Its [[specific name (botany)|specific epithet]] is the [[Latin]] adjective ''lacunosa'' meaning "with holes". The [[genus|generic]] name was originally a type of Italian herb but became associated with morels.<ref name="Nilper77">Nilsson S, Persson O.(1977) ''Fungi of Northern Europe 1: Larger Fungi (Excluding Gill Fungi)''. pp. 36–37. Penguin Books. {{ISBN|0-14-063005-8}}</ref> ''H. sulcata''; once separated, because of certain differences in the lobe structure is now dropped, or just a synonym. It was not possible to draw a clear distinction between the two.<ref name = "MarcelBon87">{{cite book | author = Marcel Bon | year = 1987 | title = The Mushrooms and Toadstools of Britain and North Western Europe | publisher = Hodder and Stoughton | isbn = 0-340-39935-X}}</ref>

==Description==
''Helvella lacunosa'' has an irregularly folded or wrinkled [[pileus (mycology)|cap]] which may be shades of slatey grey to black in colour, and measure anywhere from {{convert|1|to|10|cm|in|abbr=on|frac=2}}, though usually between {{convert|2|and|5|cm|in|round=0.5|abbr=on}}. The wrinkled ringless {{convert|3|–|15|cm|in|round=0.5|abbr=on}} high [[stipe (mycology)|stem]] is chambered within, and may be white when young and darker with age, though may be any shade of grey. The [[spore print]] is white, the oval spores average 12 x 9 [[micrometre|μm]].<ref name="arora86"/> Occasionally white capped forms are found. They may be distinguished from the creamy-white coloured ''[[Helvella crispa]]'' by the latter's furry cap undersurface and inrolled margins when young.<ref name=Ammir85/>

==Distribution and habitat==
This species is common in Eastern North America and is also found in Europe,<ref name="arora86"/> [[Varsey Rhododendron Sanctuary]] in Sikkim,<ref>{{cite journal | title=Diversity and conservation of wild mushrooms in Sikkim with special reference to Barsey Rhododendron Sanctuary | vauthors = Das K | date=2010 | journal = NeBIO | volume = 1 | issue = 2 | pages=1–13 | url=https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Kanad_Das3/publication/264886696_Diversity_and_conservation_of_wild_mushrooms_in_Sikkim_with_special_reference_to_Barsey_Rhododendron_Sanctuary/links/54ec4d6c0cf28f3e65326bd4.pdf }}</ref> Japan,<ref>{{cite journal |last= Nagao H.|year=2002 |title=Fungal flora in Chiba Pref., central Japan (III) Ascomycetes: Plectomycetes and Discomycetes |journal=Journal of the Natural History Museum and Institute Chiba  |volume=5 |issue= |pages=111–32|language=Japanese}}</ref> and China.<ref>{{cite journal |last= Zhuang WY. |year=2004|title=Preliminary survey of the Helvellaceae from Xinjiang, China |journal=Mycotaxon |volume=90 |issue=1 |pages=35–42}}</ref>
It is frequent in the [[Alpine climate|alpine]], and [[temperate]] zones of both the northern and southern hemispheres.<ref name=T.Laessoe/> 
The species occurs under [[pine]], [[oak]] and [[Douglas fir]] and nearby parkland and lawns.<ref name="arora86"/> Fruiting bodies appear in late summer and autumn, though have been recorded in winter in California.<ref name="arora86"/> It often occurs on burnt ground.<ref name = "Phillips06">{{cite book | author = Phillips R | year = 2006 | title = Mushrooms |page= 360| publisher = Pan Macmillan Ltd|location=London| isbn=0-330-44237-6}}</ref>

Two similar looking species occur in Western North America – ''[[Helvella vespertina]]'' is associated with [[conifer]]s and ''[[Helvella dryophila]]'' is associated with [[oak]]. The European ''Helvella lacunosa'' has been found in Eastern North America, but not in the west.<ref name="Nguyen 2013" />

==Edibility==
This species is eaten and regarded highly by some after cooking, though the stems are not eaten.<ref name="arora86"/> Lightfoot regarded it as edible in 1777,<ref name=lightfoot/> and several guidebooks list it as edible,<ref name = "Phillips06"/><ref name=Haas69>{{cite book | last = Haas |first=Hans | year = 1969 | title = The Young Specialist looks at Fungi |page= 184| publisher = Burke | isbn= 0-222-79409-7}}</ref> yet this genus is now regarded with suspicion due to the presence of toxic compounds in several related species. It has been reported to cause gastrointestinal symptoms when eaten raw.<ref name=Ammir85>{{cite book |last1=Ammirati |first1=Joseph F.|last2=Traquair |first2=James A. |last3=Horgen |first3=Paul A. |title=Poisonous mushrooms of the northern United States and Canada |year=1985 |publisher=University of Minnesota Press |location=Minneapolis |isbn=0-8166-1407-5 |page=259}}</ref>
